values.title: gzserver crashes when launched with ssh X-forwarding

content.raw:
gzserver crashes under xforwarding. 

I'm using close to master of gazebo. 

It appears its failing on finding software rastering drivers. 

```

values.title: VisualPlugins not registering SDF elements (Gazebo2, Indigo) -> (Gazebo7, Kinetic)

content.raw:
We're migrating our systems to ROS Kinetic, and ran into the following issue:

Plugin elements defined in the URDF [here](https://github.com/utexas-bwi/segbot/blob/master/segbot_description/urdf/components/laptop.urdf.xacro#L72) are no longer being read in the corresponding ROS Gazebo plugin [here](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/jade-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_video.cpp#L139).

This same error does not occur in case of ModelPlugins.

I've verified that running the following command (after generating the urdf from xacro works) retains the elements in the SDF 1.6 format produced. Both files are attached to this issue report:
```
gz sdf --print segbot_v2.urdf > segbot_v2.sdf
```
content.html:
We're migrating our systems to ROS Kinetic, and ran into the following issue:

Plugin elements defined in the URDF here are no longer being read in the corresponding ROS Gazebo plugin here.

This same error does not occur in case of ModelPlugins.

I've verified that running the following command (after generating the urdf from xacro works) retains the elements in the SDF 1.6 format produced. Both files are attached to this issue report:

gz sdf --print segbot_v2.urdf > segbot_v2.sdf

values.title: Model Editor joint visuals don't consider use_parent_model_frame

content.raw:
The polaris_ranger_ev model has some joints with `use_parent_model_frame=true`. It's joint visuals are displayed properly in the sim window:

![sim.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3673181146-sim.png)

but they are not displayed properly in the model editor:

![me.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/259075949-me.png)

values.title: Model Editor: inserted model doesn't have joint visuals

content.raw:
If I right-click on polaris_ranger_ev and then `Edit Model`, then insert a double pendulum in the model editor, the double pendulum doesn't have any joint visuals:

![joint_visuals.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2884505515-joint_visuals.png)
content.html: If I right-click on polaris_ranger_ev and then Edit Model, then insert a double pendulum in the model editor, the double pendulum doesn't have any joint visuals:

values.title: Model Editor: inserted model causes crash on exit

content.raw:
If I right-click on polaris_ranger_ev and `Edit Model`, then insert a double pendulum, it causes a crash when exiting the model editor (only tested without saving). The gzclient backtrace appears to implicate the schematic viewer:

~~~
newtrap: Trapezoid-table overflow 301
gzclient: trapezoid.c:88: newtrap: Assertion `0' failed.

Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
0x00007ffff6644c37 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
56	../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt

values.title: cannot change resolution of camera sensor

content.html:
I'm trying to develop a plugin which allows the user to change the resolution of a camera sensor on the fly (please stop me here if such a plugin already exists or if you can point me to a working example).

I'm doing this as follows (some code omitted):

void myplugin::setImageProperties (const double angle_hfov, const size_t width, const size_t height)
{
    m_mutex.wait();
    m_parentSensor->Update(false);
    m_parentSensor->SetActive(false);
    m_camera->SetCaptureData(false);
    m_camera->DisconnectNewImageFrame(this->m_updateConnection);

    m_camera->SetHFOV(ignition::math::Angle(angle_hfov));
    m_camera->SetImageSize(width,height);   

    m_updateConnection = m_camera->ConnectNewImageFrame(boost::bind(&myplugin::captureImage, this, _1, _2, _3, _4, _5));
    m_camera->SetCaptureData(true);
    m_parentSensor->SetActive(true);
    m_parentSensor->Update(true); // sometimes here I get segfault during Update()

    m_mutex.post();
}

bool myplugin::captureImage(const unsigned char *_image,
                          unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height,
                          unsigned int _depth, const std::string &_format)
{
  m_mutex.wait();
// here _width and _height never changes?!
  m_mutex.post();
}

However I get random segfaults (maybe a race condition inside the Update() method?) and I do not get the desired change of resolution. Am I doing it in the wrong way? I have to point out that, instead, m_camera->SetHFOV() works perfectly.

Thanks for your help.

values.title: Unit indication missing in documentation

content.raw:
Dear all,
the whole documentation is missing unit indication. Its hard to know what you have to expect if there is no velocity in [m/s] or rotation rate in [turns/s] as it could be [rad/ sec] or degree or anything else. This leaves me to testing each and every new interface I want to use ... This is really annoying for anybody who tries to get into gazebo... many of my students have complained about this ...
Sincerely yours,
Damian

values.title: Joint::SetPosition alterate the simulation

content.raw:
This is linked to an issue in gazebo_ros_pkgs where the use of a PositionJointInterface make the simulation unusable : https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/479

To reproduce the problem with gazebo and ROS you can use the rrbot on this branch : https://github.com/vincentrou/gazebo_ros_demos/tree/position_joint_interface

I find out that the ROS library calls Joint::SetPosition in gazebo.
At the end, gazebo call Link::MoveFrame.
In this [commit](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/657230d00c8bc8d90d0b3bfa99fe735498d3900b#Lgazebo/physics/Link.ccT1167), 
a line was added by @hsu (this line seems to freeze the simulation if there is a parent joint)

```
#!c++

this->SetWorldTwist(math::Vector3(0, 0, 0), math::Vector3(0, 0, 0));
```
When I remove this line everything seems to work again (like in gazebo 2).
Why this line has been added ? And should it be remove to fix the issue ?
I can make a PR.

Thank you for your great work on gazebo.
content.html:
This is linked to an issue in gazebo_ros_pkgs where the use of a PositionJointInterface make the simulation unusable : https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/479

To reproduce the problem with gazebo and ROS you can use the rrbot on this branch : https://github.com/vincentrou/gazebo_ros_demos/tree/position_joint_interface

I find out that the ROS library calls Joint::SetPosition in gazebo. At the end, gazebo call Link::MoveFrame. In this commit, a line was added by @hsu (this line seems to freeze the simulation if there is a parent joint)

this->SetWorldTwist(math::Vector3(0, 0, 0), math::Vector3(0, 0, 0));

When I remove this line everything seems to work again (like in gazebo 2). Why this line has been added ? And should it be remove to fix the issue ? I can make a PR.

Thank you for your great work on gazebo.

values.title: Attaching objects to Gripper does not work in effect.

content.raw:
Current grasp checking algorithm for gripper is:

- check contacts between objects and gripper links on every updates (update rate is `0.75` sec [1])
- if contacts exists continuously (`attach_steps` parameter is used), it starts to compute distance of every contacts. [2] 
- Latest `10` differences from the distance of contacts and one on previous time is collected. [3] (`Gripper::HandleAttach`)
- If none of these differences and their variance exceeds threshold `1e-5`, then the object are attached to the gripper link. [4]

The problem is there is hard-coded parameter `10` for computing a maximum of the latest differences of collision distances, which means we must call method `Gripper::HandleAttach` at least 10 times for regarding that objects should be attached to the gripper.
As the update rate for grippers are not so high, method `Gripper::HandleAttach` may not be called 10 times on grasp action.
So it should be better to provide option to change update rate for gripper and the hard-coded parameter `10`.
This may need to change the specification of sdformat.
How do you think about it?
And how can we change?

- [1] #!/osrf/gazebo/src/26e59bf273b5c942023552f7095a5f2d75a0a43c/gazebo/physics/Gripper.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Gripper.cc-57
- [2] #!/osrf/gazebo/src/26e59bf273b5c942023552f7095a5f2d75a0a43c/gazebo/physics/Gripper.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Gripper.cc-161
- [3] #!/osrf/gazebo/src/26e59bf273b5c942023552f7095a5f2d75a0a43c/gazebo/physics/Gripper.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Gripper.cc-227
- [4] #!/osrf/gazebo/src/26e59bf273b5c942023552f7095a5f2d75a0a43c/gazebo/physics/Gripper.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Gripper.cc-231
content.html:
Current grasp checking algorithm for gripper is:

  • check contacts between objects and gripper links on every updates (update rate is 0.75 sec [1])
  • if contacts exists continuously (attach_steps parameter is used), it starts to compute distance of every contacts. [2]
  • Latest 10 differences from the distance of contacts and one on previous time is collected. [3] (Gripper::HandleAttach)
  • If none of these differences and their variance exceeds threshold 1e-5, then the object are attached to the gripper link. [4]

The problem is there is hard-coded parameter 10 for computing a maximum of the latest differences of collision distances, which means we must call method Gripper::HandleAttach at least 10 times for regarding that objects should be attached to the gripper. As the update rate for grippers are not so high, method Gripper::HandleAttach may not be called 10 times on grasp action. So it should be better to provide option to change update rate for gripper and the hard-coded parameter 10. This may need to change the specification of sdformat. How do you think about it? And how can we change?

values.title: Specular material not working

content.raw:
See [this](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/15087/gazebo5-specular-in-material-does-not-work/) question.

The specular element in SDF is not working, but ambient, diffuse and emissive do.

A way to test this is to insert the following model in an empty world:

~~~
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.6'>
<model name='materials'>
  <static>true</static>
  <link name="ambient">
    <pose>0 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <visual name="visual">
      <material>
        <ambient>0 0 1 1</ambient>
        <diffuse>0 0 0 1</diffuse>
        <emissive>0 0 0 1</emissive>
        <specular>0 0 0 1</specular>
      </material>
      <geometry>
        <sphere>
          <radius>0.1</radius>
        </sphere>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </link>
  <link name="diffuse">
    <pose>1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <visual name="visual">
      <material>
        <ambient>0 0 0 1</ambient>
        <diffuse>0 0 1 1</diffuse>
        <emissive>0 0 0 1</emissive>
        <specular>0 0 0 1</specular>
      </material>
      <geometry>
        <sphere>
          <radius>0.1</radius>
        </sphere>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </link>
  <link name="emissive">
    <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <visual name="visual">
      <material>
        <ambient>0 0 0 1</ambient>
        <diffuse>0 0 0 1</diffuse>
        <emissive>0 0 1 1</emissive>
        <specular>0 0 0 1</specular>
      </material>
      <geometry>
        <sphere>
          <radius>0.1</radius>
        </sphere>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </link>
  <link name="specular">
    <pose>1 1 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <visual name="visual">
      <material>
        <ambient>0 0 0 1</ambient>
        <diffuse>0 0 0 1</diffuse>
        <emissive>0 0 0 1</emissive>
        <specular>0 0 1 1</specular>
      </material>
      <geometry>
        <sphere>
          <radius>0.1</radius>
        </sphere>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </link>
</model>
</sdf>
~~~

1. Then on the left panel, set the `sun`'s diffuse and specular to black. Set the `Scene`'s ambient to black.

1. Only the `emissive` link is visible.

1. Set the `sun`'s specular to white, nothing changes

1. Set the `sun`'s diffuse to white, the diffuse link turns blue

1. Set the `Scene`'s ambient to white, the ambient link turns blue

values.title: gazebo7 branch doesn't build on homebrew

content.raw: The qt4 formula was recently removed from `homebrew-core` since it has been deprecated for a while. To support older versions of gazebo, I added a `qt4-no-webkit` formula to our `osrf/simulation` tap. As the name implies, this version of qt4 is built without webkit support, since the webkit version was old and deemed a security risk. The only problem is that gazebo7 requires webkit support. I've patched the gazebo7 formula with the commits from pull request #2371, so `brew install gazebo7` works, but building the gazebo7 branch from source doesn't work. We will need to backport pull request #2371 in an API-compatible way.
content.html: The qt4 formula was recently removed from homebrew-core since it has been deprecated for a while. To support older versions of gazebo, I added a qt4-no-webkit formula to our osrf/simulation tap. As the name implies, this version of qt4 is built without webkit support, since the webkit version was old and deemed a security risk. The only problem is that gazebo7 requires webkit support. I've patched the gazebo7 formula with the commits from pull request #2371, so brew install gazebo7 works, but building the gazebo7 branch from source doesn't work. We will need to backport pull request #2371 in an API-compatible way.

values.title: Visual Studio 2015 compatibility

content.raw:
Hi everyone, 
   I have a few patches related to Visual Studio 2015 compatibility ( using dependencies obtained from [`vcpkg`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg) ) .

This fixes should not impact the public interface of the library or the existing `configure.bat`-based Visual Studio 2013 builds, so I wondered if you prefered PRs opened against `default` or against the `gazebo8` branch.
content.html:
Hi everyone, I have a few patches related to Visual Studio 2015 compatibility ( using dependencies obtained from vcpkg ) .

This fixes should not impact the public interface of the library or the existing configure.bat-based Visual Studio 2013 builds, so I wondered if you prefered PRs opened against default or against the gazebo8 branch.

values.title: Some COLLADA textures are invisible since pull request #2536

content.html:
Try inserting the "Fire Station" model for example, it will be inserted but its visuals are invisible. Another one is ARIAC's workcell.

I was able to fix this with the following patch, but I'm sure this must have unintended consequences.

diff -r c9aa7a121d3b gazebo/rendering/Material.cc
--- a/gazebo/rendering/Material.cc  Sun Jan 08 23:50:54 2017 -0800
+++ b/gazebo/rendering/Material.cc  Mon Jan 09 09:58:31 2017 -0800
@@ -155,14 +155,10 @@
   common::Color diffuse =  _mat->GetDiffuse();
   common::Color specular = _mat->GetSpecular();
   common::Color emissive = _mat->GetEmissive();
-  float transparency = _mat->GetTransparency();

-  // use transparency value if specified otherwise use diffuse alpha value
-  double alpha = transparency > 0 ? 1.0 - transparency : diffuse.a;
-  diffuse.a = alpha;
   pass->setDiffuse(diffuse.r, diffuse.g, diffuse.b, diffuse.a);
   pass->setAmbient(ambient.r, ambient.g, ambient.b);
   pass->setDepthWriteEnabled(_mat->GetDepthWrite());

values.title: Qt5: GUI overlay plugins not working?

content.raw:
When I open `timer_gui.world`, the GUI overlays don't show.

GUI plugins seem to be loaded correctly though, `KeyboardGUIPlugin` is correctly publishing key press messages in `simple_arm_teleop.world` for example.

Maybe related, when I open Gazebo without any world, I see a weird white line on the top:

![whiteline.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2237921347-whiteline.png)
content.html:
When I open timer_gui.world, the GUI overlays don't show.

GUI plugins seem to be loaded correctly though, KeyboardGUIPlugin is correctly publishing key press messages in simple_arm_teleop.world for example.

Maybe related, when I open Gazebo without any world, I see a weird white line on the top:

values.title: Qt5: No menu shortcuts are working

content.raw:
Keyboard shortcuts which show up on the top toolbar, such as rotate/translate/scale, undo, snap and plotting are working.

But shortcuts which only show up on the top menu, such as opening the building/model editor, opening the topic viewer, saving the world, closing the editors, etc, are not working. The shortcuts don't even show on the menu like they used to:

![missingshortkeys.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3886171717-missingshortkeys.png)
content.html:
Keyboard shortcuts which show up on the top toolbar, such as rotate/translate/scale, undo, snap and plotting are working.

But shortcuts which only show up on the top menu, such as opening the building/model editor, opening the topic viewer, saving the world, closing the editors, etc, are not working. The shortcuts don't even show on the menu like they used to:

values.title: Qt5: Clicking to select models in the scene doesn't work every time

content.raw:
I inserted two simple shapes and then started selecting one and then the other by clicking on them in the scene.

More than half the times, the click doesn't select the shape, I have to click a few times until it is selected.

I tried the same with gazebo7 and every click works

values.title: `gz log --echo` renders state log unplayable

content.raw:
If I have a state log captured by gazebo using `-r`, and then run a filter over it, I have issues playing back the resulting file even if no filter is used.

that is, I am simply using (for debug purposes):
```
gz log --echo --file before_small.log > after_small.log
```

and I find that `after_small.log` is not playable. I get:

```
[Err] [World.cc:2180] Unable to find model[robot]
```
printed repeatedly, while `before_small.log` is playable with

```
 rosrun gazebo_ros gazebo -p `pwd/`before_small.log --verbose --pause
```

(the `--pause` is necessary or it will not play).

I've attached the log files and the diff (txt versions). The log file was created using the software for the ARIAC competition (https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/wiki/tutorials) and involves a UR10 arm [using URDF and xacro](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/c2dadaed8763241039e389446f88f9178cb83663/osrf_gear/launch/gear.urdf.xacro.template?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#gear.urdf.xacro.template-8). Without that arm (the model "robot"), everything works fine.

I've only tried with gazebo 7.4 from debs
content.html:
If I have a state log captured by gazebo using -r, and then run a filter over it, I have issues playing back the resulting file even if no filter is used.

that is, I am simply using (for debug purposes):

gz log --echo --file before_small.log > after_small.log

and I find that after_small.log is not playable. I get:

[Err] [World.cc:2180] Unable to find model[robot]

printed repeatedly, while before_small.log is playable with

 rosrun gazebo_ros gazebo -p `pwd/`before_small.log --verbose --pause

(the --pause is necessary or it will not play).

I've attached the log files and the diff (txt versions). The log file was created using the software for the ARIAC competition (https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/wiki/tutorials) and involves a UR10 arm using URDF and xacro. Without that arm (the model "robot"), everything works fine.

I've only tried with gazebo 7.4 from debs

I always obtained the following **ERROR** message while **cmake configuration**:


```
#!c++

 CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:303 (message):

#!c++

if (build_errors)

  message(STATUS "END BUILD ERRORS\n")

values.title: NestedModels() doesn't find models in <include> tags

content.raw:
If I have an sdf with:

```
<!-- AGV1 -->
    <model name ="agv1">
      <pose>0.3 3.3 0 0 0 3.1415</pose>
      <include>
        <uri>model://warehouse_robot</uri>
      </include>
      <plugin name="agv_plugin" filename="libROSAGVPlugin.so">
        <submit_tray_service_name>/ariac/submit_tray</submit_tray_service_name>
        <index>1</index>
      </plugin>

      <!-- a tray for building kits -->
      <include>
        <uri>model://kit_tray</uri>
        <pose>0.0 0.15 0.75 0 0 0</pose>
      </include>

      <!-- join the tray and agv -->
      <joint name="agv_tray" type="fixed">
          <parent>warehouse_robot::link</parent>
          <child>kit_tray::tray</child>
      </joint>
    </model>
```

then NestedModels() on the agv1 model doesn't list `kit_tray`. It will only list the `kit_tray` model if I wrap the include in a <model> tag. I think this is caused by [this line, explicitly looking for <model> tags](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a20b41536774d4b1c7c019da6ff117c0b921cc70/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Model.cc-198)

then NestedModels() on the agv1 model doesn't list kit_tray. It will only list the kit_tray model if I wrap the include in a <model> tag. I think this is caused by this line, explicitly looking for <model> tags

values.title: World state insertions don't work for lights

content.raw:
The SDF spec accepts `<model>` tags inside `<insertions>`, but no `<light>` tags.

http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=state#state_insertions
content.html:
The SDF spec accepts <model> tags inside <insertions>, but no <light> tags.

values.title: Risk of mixing ign-math2 and ign-math3 ABIs in gazebo8

content.raw:
This issue follows up the statement made by @traversaro in a [gazebo PR](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2588/depend-on-ign-math3/diff#comment-29577581):

*"If there is an ABI breakage between ign-math2 and ign-math3, ign-msgs functions would use ign-math2's ABI, while Gazebo would use ign-math3's ABI, with runtime errors when Gazebo is calling ign-msgs functions that use ignition::math objects."*

Given that we are exposing the same symbols in ign-math2 and ign-math3, there is a risk of ABI breakage if those are being exposed in the public interfaces of the different ignition robotics libraries.

**Short-term action:**
In order to avoid the potential risk in gazebo8, I proposed to migrate all the gazebo dependencies to ign-math3, release them and make gazebo8 to depend strictly on those versions using ign-math3 or newer.

**Proper solution:**
To avoid the binary symbol conflict we can expore the option of using [`inline namespaces`](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/namespace#Inline_namespaces) in the different ignition libraries. The method is described for [libstdc++](https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/libstdc%2B%2B/manual/using_dual_abi.html) or in the [mongdb project](http://mongodb.github.io/mongo-cxx-driver/mongocxx-v3/api-abi-versioning/)
content.html:
This issue follows up the statement made by @traversaro in a gazebo PR:

"If there is an ABI breakage between ign-math2 and ign-math3, ign-msgs functions would use ign-math2's ABI, while Gazebo would use ign-math3's ABI, with runtime errors when Gazebo is calling ign-msgs functions that use ignition::math objects."

Given that we are exposing the same symbols in ign-math2 and ign-math3, there is a risk of ABI breakage if those are being exposed in the public interfaces of the different ignition robotics libraries.

Short-term action: In order to avoid the potential risk in gazebo8, I proposed to migrate all the gazebo dependencies to ign-math3, release them and make gazebo8 to depend strictly on those versions using ign-math3 or newer.

Proper solution: To avoid the binary symbol conflict we can expore the option of using inline namespaces in the different ignition libraries. The method is described for libstdc++ or in the mongdb project

values.title: Some plot search results don't highlight until hover

content.raw:
It looks like the paint event not always triggered. How to reproduce:

1. Open gazebo with an empty world

1. Open the plot window

1. On the search tab, slowly type "plane". The word is only partially highlighted in different places.

1. Hover the mouse over the results, and the highlighting fixes itself

  1. Open gazebo with an empty world

  2. Open the plot window

  3. On the search tab, slowly type "plane". The word is only partially highlighted in different places.

  4. Hover the mouse over the results, and the highlighting fixes itself

values.title: Model editor: support joints to the world

content.raw:
It would be nice to be able to specify the world as the parent of a joint in the editor.

A more pressing issue is to at least not remove joints to the world, as it's currently doing:

1. Open a world which has a joint to the world, for example: `force_torque_demo.world`

1. Right-click the model which has the joint to the world and select "Edit Model"

1. Don't change anything, just exit and save

1. Back in simulation, when you press play, the model falls because the joint has been removed
content.html:
It would be nice to be able to specify the world as the parent of a joint in the editor.

A more pressing issue is to at least not remove joints to the world, as it's currently doing:

  1. Open a world which has a joint to the world, for example: force_torque_demo.world

  2. Right-click the model which has the joint to the world and select "Edit Model"

  3. Don't change anything, just exit and save

  4. Back in simulation, when you press play, the model falls because the joint has been removed

values.title: When translating, the snap to grid hotkey doesn't work together with XYZ keys

content.raw:
Dragging the model on translate mode (dragging the model directly, not one of the 3 arrows) translates the model on the XY plane. Holding the Ctrl key while dragging snaps to the 1 m grid.

While doing this, it's possible to hold the X, Y or Z keys to constrain the motion to these axes.

But if one tries to use the Ctrl key to snap to grid while holding X, Y or Z, the dragging behavior goes back to being on the XY plane.
content.html:
Dragging the model on translate mode (dragging the model directly, not one of the 3 arrows) translates the model on the XY plane. Holding the Ctrl key while dragging snaps to the 1 m grid.

While doing this, it's possible to hold the X, Y or Z keys to constrain the motion to these axes.

But if one tries to use the Ctrl key to snap to grid while holding X, Y or Z, the dragging behavior goes back to being on the XY plane.

values.title: Scaling XYZ hotkeys don't work well if not aligned with the world

content.raw:
1. Insert a box and choose the scaling tool

1. Drag the box (not one of the 3 markers) while holding the X key and only the X axis scales

1. Now use the rotate tool to rotate the box about the Z axis

1. Using the scale tool again, repeat number 2. The box scales on both X and Y axes, instead of only on X.
content.html:
1. Insert a box and choose the scaling tool

  2. Drag the box (not one of the 3 markers) while holding the X key and only the X axis scales

  3. Now use the rotate tool to rotate the box about the Z axis

  4. Using the scale tool again, repeat number 2. The box scales on both X and Y axes, instead of only on X.

values.title: Message API documentation broken?

content.raw:
1. Go to http://gazebosim.org/api

1. Click on Messages API dev : http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/msg-api/dev/classes.html

1. Click on any message, for example: http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/msg-api/dev/interfaceWorldStatistics.html

values.title: Visual rotation marker should indicate the axis of rotation when using hotkeys

content.raw:
When the user has selected a rotation tool and presses one of the hotkeys, the marker should change to reflect that hotkey rotation happens in the global frame.

Currently rotating twice with hotkeys causes second rotation to be different from the rotation indicated by the visual marker:

1. Drag a box into the world
2. Press `r` to use the rotate tool
3. Hold `x` then left-click drag the model until the Blue ring (z axis rotation) is vertical
4. Hold `z` then left-click drag the model

![rotate_keyboard_shortcut_bug.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2850240815-rotate_keyboard_shortcut_bug.gif)


When a hotkey is pressed the marker could change to a single ring around the model oriented with the global axis the hotkey pertains to. If the 'z' key is pressed, the current marker would disappear, and a blue ring would appear around the model aligned with the global Z axis.
content.html:
When the user has selected a rotation tool and presses one of the hotkeys, the marker should change to reflect that hotkey rotation happens in the global frame.

Currently rotating twice with hotkeys causes second rotation to be different from the rotation indicated by the visual marker:

  1. Drag a box into the world
  2. Press r to use the rotate tool
  3. Hold x then left-click drag the model until the Blue ring (z axis rotation) is vertical
  4. Hold z then left-click drag the model

When a hotkey is pressed the marker could change to a single ring around the model oriented with the global axis the hotkey pertains to. If the 'z' key is pressed, the current marker would disappear, and a blue ring would appear around the model aligned with the global Z axis.

values.title: gz log filter joints test has wrong expectations

content.raw:
I was trying to use a joint filter on a log file the same way as it is done on [UNIT_gz_log_TEST](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8d35d7d913a368dc6d39105fa42c4ff05a4e858e/tools/gz_log_TEST.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#gz_log_TEST.cc-215), but couldn't get any joint information any way I tried.

Then I tried using the same command as the test uses on the same [file](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8d35d7d913a368dc6d39105fa42c4ff05a4e858e/test/data/pr2_state.log?fileviewer=file-view-default), and I noticed that that file doesn't even have joint information in the unfiltered version.

If we add a print statement to the test:

~~~
diff -r a1aebcb971ad tools/gz_log_TEST.cc
--- a/tools/gz_log_TEST.cc	Thu Jan 19 10:52:31 2017 -0800
+++ b/tools/gz_log_TEST.cc	Fri Jan 20 16:34:48 2017 -0800
@@ -216,6 +216,7 @@
   echo = custom_exec(std::string(GZ_LOG_PATH +
         " -e --filter pr2//r_upper_arm_roll_joint -f ") +
       PROJECT_SOURCE_PATH + "/test/data/pr2_state.log");
+std::cout << echo;
   shasum = gazebo::common::get_sha1<std::string>(echo);
   // EXPECT_EQ(pr2JointStateLog, echo);
   if (std::string("1.4").compare(SDF_VERSION) == 0)
~~~

We can see that the result doesn't contain any joint information, only a empty model states like this:

~~~
<model name='pr2'>
</model>
~~~

So I believe the shasums used on that test were created based on invalid expectations. 

I'm not even sure if joint filtering works at all, in fact, it looks like log files don't usually contain joint states...

If we add a print statement to the test:

--- a/tools/gz_log_TEST.cc  Thu Jan 19 10:52:31 2017 -0800

We can see that the result doesn't contain any joint information, only a empty model states like this:

<model name='pr2'>
</model>

So I believe the shasums used on that test were created based on invalid expectations.

I'm not even sure if joint filtering works at all, in fact, it looks like log files don't usually contain joint states...

values.title: Renaming a model does not rename the fullscoped names of its childs

content.raw: As the title says. When we rename a model using a world or model plugin, the scope names of its childs remains the same. This is critical, when we want to spawn severeal instances of one model type and access their childs later. Thus, the scope names of e.g. attached sensors are not unique.

values.title: ODE contact points not displaying on bodies which are not moving

content.raw:
ODE has a nice feature to automatically disable bodies when they are not moving. This is great for performance. However there is one issue with this.
ODEPhysics skips disabled bodies in [ODEPhysics::CollisionCallback](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d9caf6c36a9f78ce6ab2a1fa2f7ddef06084d889/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODEPhysics.cc-965) which is called from [ODEPhysics::UpdateCollision](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d9caf6c36a9f78ce6ab2a1fa2f7ddef06084d889/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODEPhysics.cc-382).

This affects computation of the contact points in the function [ODEPhysics::Collide()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d9caf6c36a9f78ce6ab2a1fa2f7ddef06084d889/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODEPhysics.cc-1004) which is then called later for all bodies not skipped in CollisionCallback. So in effect, no contact points are computed for links which are not moving and which are in contact with other non-moving links. This is certainly done for performance reasons.

The issue with this is: ODEPhysics::Collide() adds the contact information to the physics::ContactManager. But Collide() is only called for enabled bodies. Now if there is a subscriber to the contact points topic, they would not receive the contact points between the not moving links. But depending on the application, subscribers may also need the contact points between still objects. Example: the gzclient visualization doesn't show objects which are still. This can be tested by:

1. Starting gazebo in paused mode
2. Putting a sphere on the ground
3. Switching on Contacts visualization
4. Hit Play
5. Waiting until the object is still: The contact point will disappear.

This doesn't happen with Bullet.

I found this can be solved by [some changes to ContactPointManager in my branch contact_manager_enforcable_additions](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/diff/gazebo/physics/ContactManager.hh?diff2=0098d8d9839f&at=contact_manager_enforcable_additions#Lgazebo/physics/ContactManager.hhT106) (see also pull request #2629) and changing following lines in ODEPhysics::CollisionCallback:

```cpp
    // Exit if both bodies are not enabled
    if (dGeomGetCategoryBits(_o1) != GZ_SENSOR_COLLIDE &&
        dGeomGetCategoryBits(_o2) != GZ_SENSOR_COLLIDE &&
        !self->contactManager->ContactsEnforced() &&
        !self->contactManager->SubscribersConnected(collision1, collision2) &&
        ((b1 && b2 && !dBodyIsEnabled(b1) && !dBodyIsEnabled(b2)) ||
        (!b2 && b1 && !dBodyIsEnabled(b1)) ||
        (!b1 && b2 && !dBodyIsEnabled(b2))))
    {
      return;
    }
```

Effectively this enforces the treatment of colliding objects if there are subscribers to the contact points (or if has been enforced for another reason).

However my only concern with this is that ODEPhysics::Collide() does not only fill in the contact point feedback, but also [creates contact joints](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d9caf6c36a9f78ce6ab2a1fa2f7ddef06084d889/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODEPhysics.cc-1280). I am not sure how they are used, and if this could badly impact performance while there are any contact point subscribers.

Any feedback on this would be appreciated so I can try to fix this up.
content.html:
ODE has a nice feature to automatically disable bodies when they are not moving. This is great for performance. However there is one issue with this. ODEPhysics skips disabled bodies in ODEPhysics::CollisionCallback which is called from ODEPhysics::UpdateCollision.

This affects computation of the contact points in the function ODEPhysics::Collide() which is then called later for all bodies not skipped in CollisionCallback. So in effect, no contact points are computed for links which are not moving and which are in contact with other non-moving links. This is certainly done for performance reasons.

The issue with this is: ODEPhysics::Collide() adds the contact information to the physics::ContactManager. But Collide() is only called for enabled bodies. Now if there is a subscriber to the contact points topic, they would not receive the contact points between the not moving links. But depending on the application, subscribers may also need the contact points between still objects. Example: the gzclient visualization doesn't show objects which are still. This can be tested by:

  1. Starting gazebo in paused mode
  2. Putting a sphere on the ground
  3. Switching on Contacts visualization
  4. Hit Play
  5. Waiting until the object is still: The contact point will disappear.

This doesn't happen with Bullet.

I found this can be solved by some changes to ContactPointManager in my branch contact_manager_enforcable_additions (see also pull request #2629) and changing following lines in ODEPhysics::CollisionCallback:

    // Exit if both bodies are not enabled
    if (dGeomGetCategoryBits(_o1) != GZ_SENSOR_COLLIDE &&
        dGeomGetCategoryBits(_o2) != GZ_SENSOR_COLLIDE &&
        !self->contactManager->ContactsEnforced() &&
        !self->contactManager->SubscribersConnected(collision1, collision2) &&
        ((b1 && b2 && !dBodyIsEnabled(b1) && !dBodyIsEnabled(b2)) ||
        (!b2 && b1 && !dBodyIsEnabled(b1)) ||
        (!b1 && b2 && !dBodyIsEnabled(b2))))
    {
      return;
    }

Effectively this enforces the treatment of colliding objects if there are subscribers to the contact points (or if has been enforced for another reason).

However my only concern with this is that ODEPhysics::Collide() does not only fill in the contact point feedback, but also creates contact joints. I am not sure how they are used, and if this could badly impact performance while there are any contact point subscribers.

Any feedback on this would be appreciated so I can try to fix this up.

values.title: Models broken in DART 4

content.raw:
Hi,

I tried to run SRCSIM using DART engine but once the robot get inserted the all the links will break down and go to the origin. Similar problem happened to the model of PR2, Pioneer 2DX, iRobot Hand and maybe more. I'm using Gazebo 7.5 with DART4-dev.

I saw same problem in #1435, is there any updates on this problem?
Thanks!

![default_gzclient_camera(1)-2017-02-02T17_42_55.107761.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1473273513-default_gzclient_camera1)-2017-02-02T17_42_55.107761.jpg)

values.title: LinkState pose: is it relative or world?

content.html:
This is more of a question than an issue at this point, but it could be that there are discrepancies in the documentation or usage of LinkState / Link.

I want to create a physics::LinkState out of a msgs::Link message. I noticed then that in Link::SetState, the world pose is used:

//////////////////////////////////////////////////
void Link::SetState(const LinkState &_state)
{
  this->SetWorldPose(_state.Pose());
...

However in LinkState, the documentation says this is the pose relative to the model:

      /// \brief 3D pose of the link relative to the model.
      private: ignition::math::Pose3d pose;

and the relative pose is also what is being used in Link::ProcessMsg 

 if (_msg.has_pose())
  {
    this->SetEnabled(true);
    this->SetRelativePose(msgs::ConvertIgn(_msg.pose()));
  }

Does msgs::Link use the relative pose, while the physics::LinkState uses world pose? Or are they both meant to use the relative pose? Unless I'm missing something here, in the former case, the comment in LinkState should be updated, in the latter Link::SetState has to set the relative pose instead of the world pose.

values.title: UserCmdManager does not use world name to initialize node

content.html:
I stumbled over something which could be a minor bug in UserCmdManager. When initializing the node, it is not using the world name, but instead defaults to taking the first available namespace loaded (which is was happens if Node::Init() is called with empty string parameter).

Because usually there is only one world loaded, that has probably never shown up to be a problem. But if several worlds are loaded, loading a world after another namespace has already been added will use the wrong topic names.

In UserCmdManager.cpp this affects only one line in Init():

/////////////////////////////////////////////////
UserCmdManager::UserCmdManager(const WorldPtr _world)
  : dataPtr(new UserCmdManagerPrivate())
{
  this->dataPtr->world = _world;

  this->dataPtr->node = transport::NodePtr(new transport::Node());
  this->dataPtr->node->Init();
  // THIS SHOULD INSTEAD BE:
  // this->dataPtr->node->Init(_world->Name());
...

The change is included in this branch, let me know if I should send a PR for this.

values.title: GpuRaySensor sees through objects with minimum range set to 1 meter

content.raw:
The GpuRaySensor will see through objects if it's minimum range is set to 1 meter. The range at which it will do so depends on where the object is. It appears to be worse towards the edges of the cameras. The picture below should be using two Ogre cameras, it's worse in the middle where the cameras meet, and at the far ends of the scan.

![gpu_ray_passes_through_obstacles.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3228242397-gpu_ray_passes_through_obstacles.png)
content.html: The GpuRaySensor will see through objects if it's minimum range is set to 1 meter. The range at which it will do so depends on where the object is. It appears to be worse towards the edges of the cameras. The picture below should be using two Ogre cameras, it's worse in the middle where the cameras meet, and at the far ends of the scan.

values.title: GpuRaySensor sees through objects within minimum range

content.raw:
Similar to #1564, but with the GPU ray sensor.

The GpuRaySensor also sees through objects within it's minimum range. This is caused by the near clip setting on the camera used to do the measurement. While the CPU sensor rays will hit the inside of an object, the rays from a GPU do not 'see' the back side of faces, so the rays appear to go completely through the object.

![gazebo_magic_rays_gpu.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4148950147-gazebo_magic_rays_gpu.png)
content.html:
Similar to #1564, but with the GPU ray sensor.

The GpuRaySensor also sees through objects within it's minimum range. This is caused by the near clip setting on the camera used to do the measurement. While the CPU sensor rays will hit the inside of an object, the rays from a GPU do not 'see' the back side of faces, so the rays appear to go completely through the object.

values.title: Gazebo7 Linking Error with CMake / Catkin - pthreads

content.raw:
Based on discussions with @j-rivero on [this](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/pull/537#discussion_r100673551) gazebo_ros_pkgs pull request, I've isolated some sort of flag export build problem that results in the error:

```
CMake Error at /home/dave/ros/current/ws_gazebo_test/devel_release/share/base_pkg/cmake/base_pkgConfig.cmake:141 (message):
  Project 'dummy_pkg' tried to find library '-lpthread'.  The library is
  neither a target nor built/installed properly.  Did you compile project
  'base_pkg'? Did you find_package() it before the subdirectory containing
  its code is included?
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /opt/ros/kinetic/share/catkin/cmake/catkinConfig.cmake:76 (find_package)
  CMakeLists.txt:6 (find_package)
```

I think the problem is Gazebo7 is exporting a dependency on ``pthread`` which is suggested is bad on [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21981865/ld-library-not-found-for-lpthread).

This occurs when one catkin package depends on Gazebo, and another depends on that package:

**base_pkg CMakeLists**
```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 2.8.3)
project(base_pkg)

find_package(catkin REQUIRED COMPONENTS
  roscpp
)

find_package(GAZEBO REQUIRED)
set(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} ${GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS}")

find_package(Boost REQUIRED COMPONENTS thread)

include_directories(
  ${catkin_INCLUDE_DIRS}
)

catkin_package(
  DEPENDS
    Boost
    GAZEBO
)
```

**dependent pkg CMakeLists**
```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 2.8.3)
project(dummy_pkg)

find_package(catkin REQUIRED COMPONENTS
  base_pkg
)

include_directories(
  ${catkin_INCLUDE_DIRS}
)

catkin_package(
  CATKIN_DEPENDS
    base_pkg
)
```

The full workspace can be tested from this barebones [test repo](https://github.com/davetcoleman/dummy_gazebo_ws) I've just created.

Let me know how to fix this. This will also fix the Jenkins build failures on all gazebo_ros_pkgs pull requests.

values.title: Gazebo crashes if the heightmap is not of resolution 2^n+1

content.raw:
Heightmaps are required to be of resolution 2^n+1, which is fine, but gazebo crashes if the heightmap is not of this size.

It prints these errors
```
[Err] [HeightmapShape.cc:186] Heightmap data size must be square, with a size of 2^n+1
[Err] [Heightmap.cc:503] EXCEPTION: Heightmap image size must be square, with a size of 2^n+1
```

Followed by
```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'gazebo::common::Exception'
```

Possibly some extra info in comments on #1653 and #2191

values.title: Gazebo configuration missing variables?

content.raw: Trying to build Gazebo on VS2015.  Running the configuration in cmake-gui comes to a halt because CMake wants to know where Ogre3D and libcurl are.  But there's no path variables provided to assign paths...
